title: The Flood Subsides
shortSummary: Genesis 8 describes the receding of the floodwaters after God's judgment, the resting of Noah's ark on Mount Ararat, and the eventual exit of Noah and all living creatures from the ark. It highlights God's faithfulness in preserving life and His covenantal promise to never again destroy the earth by flood.
timeline: c. 2300 BC - The Flood and its aftermath

keyCharacters.name: Noah
keyCharacters.description: The righteous man chosen by God to build the ark and preserve life through the flood; he obeys God's commands and leads his family and animals out of the ark.

keyCharacters.name: Noah's Wife
keyCharacters.description: The faithful wife of Noah who accompanies him and their sons during the flood and the repopulation of the earth.

keyCharacters.name: Noah's Sons
keyCharacters.description: Shem, Ham, and Japheth, who, along with their wives, accompany Noah in the ark and participate in the renewal of life on earth.

definitions.definition: The large vessel built by Noah under God's instruction to preserve human and animal life during the flood.
Animals considered ritually pure and acceptable for sacrifice, as distinguished from unclean animals.
The subterranean springs or sources of the great waters that contributed to the flood.
A pleasing aroma to God, often associated with acceptable burnt offerings and sacrifices.

outline.heading: God Remembers Noah and the Waters Recede
outline.description: God remembers Noah and all living creatures, causing the floodwaters to subside and the ark to rest on Mount Ararat, demonstrating God's control over creation and His faithfulness to His promises.

outline.heading: Noah Sends Out Birds to Test the Earth
outline.description: Noah sends a raven and then a dove to determine if the earth is dry, symbolizing hope and the gradual restoration of life after judgment.

outline.heading: The Earth Dries and Noah Exits the Ark
outline.description: After the earth dries, God commands Noah and his family to leave the ark with all living creatures, marking the new beginning for humanity and creation.

outline.heading: Noah’s Sacrifice and God’s Promise
outline.description: Noah builds an altar and offers sacrifices to God, who accepts them and promises never to curse the ground again or destroy all life by flood, establishing a covenant of mercy.

application: Trust in God's faithfulness and timing, especially in seasons of trial and waiting, knowing He remembers His covenant promises.
Practice obedience by following God's instructions even when circumstances seem uncertain or difficult, as Noah did by building the ark and sending out the birds.
Offer thanksgiving and worship to God for His mercy and provision, recognizing His sovereignty over all creation.
Live with hope and confidence in God's sustaining power, trusting that He will bring restoration after judgment.

keyVerses.text: And God remembered Noah, and every living thing, and all the cattle that was with him in the ark: and God made a wind to pass over the earth, and the waters asswaged;
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's mercy and faithfulness in remembering Noah and initiating the end of the flood.

keyVerses.text: And Noah builded an altar unto the LORD; and took of every clean beast, and of every clean fowl, and offered burnt offerings on the altar.
keyVerses.significance: Noah's sacrifice signifies gratitude and worship, setting a pattern for honoring God after deliverance.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD smelled a sweet savour; and the LORD said in his heart, I will not again curse the ground any more for man's sake; for the imagination of man's heart is evil from his youth; neither will I again smite any more every thing living, as I have done.
keyVerses.significance: God’s promise here reveals His mercy and the enduring consequences of human sinfulness.

keyVerses.text: While the earth remaineth, seedtime and harvest, and cold and heat, and summer and winter, and day and night shall not cease.
keyVerses.significance: This verse assures the stability of creation and God’s ongoing providence despite human sin.
